repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
A central tenet of our deprecation strategy is that deprecated functions must have zero footprint in docs, auto-completion, and meta structures. The upside is that it greatly reduces the urge to remove the actual *implementation*, so legacy programmatic consumers can worry less about migrating.

(Note: formal "deprecation strategy" proposal is still WIP, but the above is not debatable.)

comment_data.body: What does this special casing achieve?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -345,8 +345,10 @@ local function render_api_meta(_f, fun, write)
   local params = process_params(fun.params)
   for _, p in ipairs(params) do
     param_names[#param_names + 1] = p[1]
-    local pdesc = p[3]
-    if pdesc then
+    local pdesc = not fun.deprecated and p[3] or nil
+    if fun.deprecated then -- luacheck: ignore 542
+      -- Skip @param description for deprecated functions.

comment_regular_data.body:
> and meta structures.

I'm against this. The meta structures are useful to communicate to a user that a function is deprecated (with `@deprecated`) with an optional message of when. Without this it can be confusing if the function exists or is spelled incorrectly.

It also causes more friction for plugins that support older versions of Nvim.

> The upside is that it greatly reduces the urge to remove the actual implementation

You remove the urge by incorporating removal into the deprecation strategy.

> The meta structures are useful to communicate to a user that a function is deprecated (with `@deprecated`) with an optional message of when.

I will consider adding the signatures and `@deprecated` note, but still removing the rest of the docs.

> > The upside is that it greatly reduces the urge to remove the actual implementation
> 
> You remove the urge by incorporating removal into the deprecation strategy.

That is the inverse approach. Note that both approaches are part of the strategy, but reducing the urgency of removals will buy time and reduce work, while also allowing more experimentation.

> I will consider adding the signatures and @deprecated note, but still removing the rest of the docs.

Fine with that. That'll at least maintain any deprecated diagnostics.

> but reducing the urgency of removals will buy time and reduce work, while also allowing more experimentation

I'm not sure how it allows more experimentation? The depreciation strategy is what allows that. It's why I proposed it.

For basic aliases this might make some sense, but they have the least (almost zero) urgency for removal. For complicated functions, there is often a large urgency to remove implementations that have a larger cone of influence over the codebase, in which their removal arguably buys time and reduces work.

> how it allows more experimentation?

Reducing the cost of potential deprecations reduces friction for introducing (some classes of) new interfaces in the first place.
I'm not sure how this reduces the cost of deprecations. The usual cost of deprecations is the ongoing maintenance of said deprecated functions.

> The usual cost of deprecations is the ongoing maintenance of said deprecated functions.

Like I said I'm working on a proposal that eliminates that problem. 

The cost of deprecations is:

1. (high) managing the migration lifecycle (for hard deprecations)
2. (high) downstream breakage (for hard deprecations)
3. (high) permanent cognitive/discoverability cost of documentation/api surface area (for both users and maintainers)
4. (high) bug fixes
5. (high) presence of old "dead" code amongst "live" code.
6. (low) size/performance cost + cost of the mere presence of the code "somewhere in the codebase"

For some types of "low-dependency / low-complexity" interfaces, we can totally eliminate 1-5, while paying the minor cost of 6, by (1) refusing all maintenance / bug fixes, (2) hiding the implementation in a "nuclear waste" part of the codebase. That's a good tradeoff. It won't be a uniform policy but it makes total sense to employ this for cases that will be outlined in the proposal.

This change introduces a high cost to users who will lack the documentation required to migrate code.

The existence of the documentation and added surface (3) is a low cost provided the functions are marked accordingly. It's not like users read the full documentation from start to finish and force themselves to remember it. It's simply reference material.

> This change introduces a high cost to users who will lack the documentation required to migrate code.

It introduces some cost there, but the docs are still available in various places, just not in our main tree. And removing something entirely is a higher cost, which can be delayed or avoided for cases that take this approach.

> which can be delayed or avoided for cases that take this approach.

Why? I don't understand how removing the docs has any bearing whatsoever. The meta information isn't even in the documentation, it's just something that exists to be consumed by tools so they have stronger semantic understanding. The cost to keep that is zero, especially in this case where it's generated.

If you don't want to remove these functions then just say that. Otherwise what's stopping someone removing them in a follow-up?

I second @lewis6991 stance here.

From API consumer perspective, a common workflow is:

- You see a function marked as deprecated (requires the metainfo for luals to do that)
- You read the docs (hoping it contains a pointer about what to do about the deprecation)
- You change the call accordingly.

If we remove the metainfo it reduces the chance that plugin authors discover deprecations early. If we remove the docs, it makes it harder for them to figure out how to act.

This is _increasing_ friction for deprecations, not lowering it from a consumer point of view.

And from a maintainer point of view leaving both in has almost no costs. Docs are not coupled to anything else - there is no interaction with other systems that would cause pain (unless the edge case of changing the doc system)

The cognitive load of seeing a deprecated function is also not that high - as long as it's clear that the function is documented.

We can make this conditional on the api-level where a function was deprecated.

For example in this very PR, notice how 20-year-old vimscript functions are in the meta info. Those things exist only for "ABI" compat. Removing most human-visible evidence allows us to keep things around longer for programmatic compat, while still achieving the other benefits of deprecation.

By making this conditional on the *age* of the deprecation, this allows us to buy time.

There is no good reason that `buffer_exists` should appear in completion or documentation.

Docs absolutely are a maintainer and user cost, they increase false-positives when searching for stuff.

There is no "buying time" here. You either keep the ~docs~ metadata or not. Neither of those decisions has any bearing of how long the depreciations continue to exist for. They exist for as long as we allow them to.

In fact I think they may be out of time anyway... 

Have you considered just removing these? If they are not valuable enough to keep ~documentation~ metadata for, then they are not valuable enough to keep. Their implementation may be tiny, but their usage will also be.

If you don't want these to appear in completion, then lobby LuaLS to avoid showing deprecated functions in completion.

> There is no "buying time" here.

I don't know why you just declare that. There obviously is. I have made the point over and over that programmatic compat can be maintained longer, while gaining the rest of the benefits of a deprecation. That is a monotonic gain, there is no (net) cost.

Please just avoid reacting and commenting on this until I have the full proposal, which I then hope people will mentally process in full instead of with partial information and assumptions.

> Have you considered just removing these? If they are not valuable enough to keep ~documentation~ metadata for, then they are not valuable enough to keep. Their implementation may be tiny, but their usage is likely zero (or very close to).

The point is that we can avoid making that decision for longer, for more things. That is very high leverage. I don't want to spend time weighing the costs of breaking programmatic compat if I can gain 95% of the benefits without doing that.

The particular case that I pointed out is irrelevant. What matters is the general practice that will help us permanently and continually.

> If you don't want these to appear in completion, then lobby LuaLS to avoid showing deprecated functions in completion.

I am referring to Nvim cmdline completion also. And I am not going to lobby anyone when I can solve things at the source.

title: docs: drop meta info for deprecated functions
